abstract.p: This article presents a methodology for modeling aggregated disease incidence data with the spatially continuous log-Gaussian Cox process. Statistical models for spatially aggregated disease incidence data usually assign the same relative risk to all individuals in the same reporting region (census areas or postal regions). A further assumption that the relative risks in two regions are independent given their neighbor's risks (the Markov assumption) makes the commonly used Besag–York–Mollié model computationally simple. The continuous model proposed here uses a data augmentation step to sample from the posterior distribution of the exact locations at each step of an Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm, and models the exact locations with an log-Gaussian Cox process. A simulation study shows the log-Gaussian Cox process model consistently outperforming the Besag–York–Mollié model. The method is illustrated by making inference on the spatial distribution of syphilis risk in North Carolina. The effect of several known social risk factors are estimated, and areas with risk well in excess of that expected given these risk factors are identified.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: Making inference on the spatial distribution of disease risk typically involves modeling spatially aggregated data. The study region is divided into smaller areas, either census regions, administrative areas, or postal or zip codes. When case counts in each region are large, the standardized incidence ratio (SIR) of observed to expected count is a reliable estimate of disease risk. Treating the SIRs as a Normally distributed response variable in subsequent spatial analyses is not uncommon outside the statistical literature.1 A more satisfactory approach, which is essential when counts are close to zero, is to model the observed count as Poisson distributed with the (logged) expected count being an offset parameter.

Modeling spatial dependence in aggregated data is occasionally performed using continuous spatial models and specifying the centroid of each area as the location of each observation. More commonly, a discretely defined spatial model is used where each region's relative risk is dependent on neighboring regions. This latter approach is the basis of the popular model from Besag, York and Mollié,2 which has come to be known as the BYM model (see also Lawson3). Letting Yr and Er be the observed and expected cases counts for the observation on region Dr; r = 1… R, the model is written as Yr~Poisson(Erλr)amp;log(λr)=μ+Xrβ+Uramp;Ur~BYM(σ2,τ2).

Here Xr are region level covariates (e.g. average income and education levels) with coefficients β, and μ is an intercept parameter. The random spatial process Ur is the sum of an independent Gaussian process Vr with variance τ2 and a Gaussian Markov random field (GMRF) Wr with variance σ2. The GMRF component has in each region's value depending on the average from the neighboring regions with Wr|Wq;q≠r~N(mean{Wq;Dq⋈Dr},σ2/|Dq⋈Dr|). The relation Dq ⋈ Dr signifies regions q and r being neighbors and sharing a common boundary, with the denominator in the variance term signifying the number of neighbors of Dr. Increasing the ratio of σ2 to τ2 increases the spatial dependence of Ur, resulting in a smoother surface. This model has become popular due to its practical usability, easy interpretation and computational simplicity. The neighborhood-based correlation structure results in the inverse of the variance matrix for Wr being sparse and with non-zero elements being simple to compute. Statistical inference is therefore computationally feasible even when the number of regions is large. Bayesian inference using Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithms is possible with a number of software packages.4,5 A recent alternative to MCMC is integrated nested Laplace approximation (INLA6).

Problems in spatial epidemiology involving case locations, as opposed to spatially aggregated case counts, are typically cast in terms of spatial point processes.7 The inhomogeneous K-function8 can be used to test the hypothesis that case locations are independent given specified intensity surface, typically proportional to the population density. In other words, the K-function tests whether cases tend to cluster together more than the population distribution would predict, perhaps due to a spatially varying risk factor or direct transmission between individuals. Once this hypothesis is rejected, however, making inference on the spatial distribution of relative risk requires more complex and less commonly used methodology.

Log-Gaussian Cox process (LGCP) models locations Pk of cases k = 1… K as an inhomogeneous Poisson process (IPP) conditional on a latent Gaussian random field U(s) and known offset surface O(s). The LGCP can be written as {Pk;k=1…K}~IPP[λ(s)O(s)]log[λ(s)]=X(s)'β+U(s)Cov[U(s),U(s+h)]=σ2ρ(h;φ).

The range parameter φ of the spatial correlation function ρ controls the roughness of the relative risk surface, with large ranges implying strong correlation and smoother surfaces. Diggle et al.9 used a spatio-temporal LGCP with an approximation enabling frequentist inference. Benes et al.10 use The LGCP to model disease incidence with MCMC-based inference. Li et al.11 use INLA and the Markov random field approximation of Lindgren et al.12 for U(s) when modeling Lupus risk, with a similar approach used to model tree locations by Illian et al.13 The computational difficulty in fitting LGCP's is the likely reason this model is much less common than the BYM model.

This article proposes a methodology for making inference on the spatially continuous LGCP model with spatially aggregated case count data. The BYM model can be seen as a special case of an LGCP where relative risk is assumed to be piecewise constant within regions. This assumption may be reasonable if the regions are, for example, school districts or hospital catchment areas which could be expected to influence disease risk. However, it is an unnatural assumption when the boundaries are arbitrary and unrelated to the biological process being modelled, as would be the case with census regions. A more consequential shortcoming of the BYM model is that boundaries influence the spatial correlation. Census regions are often large in rural areas and much smaller in populated urban centres, resulting the BYM model having strong spatial correlation between rural individuals even at long distances. In contrast, two urban individuals living in close proximity but separated by tiny census regions would be conditionally independent. The LGCP model used here specifies a stationary covariance structure, where dependence is a function of distance and not of boundaries. Coarse spatial aggregation in rural areas may reduce the precision of the estimated of the risk surface in rural locations, but aggregation will not influence spatial correlation in the LGCP model.

This method is illustrated with its application to modeling syphilis risk in North Carolina for the 9 years till 2007. The research questions are first to quantify and make inference on the influence of several measured spatially varying risk factors, and second to detect locations with risk above what would be reasonably expected given the distribution of risk factors. For reasons of confidentiality, only total case counts for each of North Carolina's 1554 census tracts are made available. The model and covariates to include were motivated by the closely related work of Sullivan et al.,14 which used a BYM model to explore the social determinants of gonorrhea risk in the same location. The consideration of the LGCP for the syphilis data used here is motivated by the lower case counts (hence less precise estimation) for syphilis compared to gonorrhea. For the syphilis data, 524 out of the 1554 census tracts in North Carolina had case counts of zero or one over the study period. sec.title: 2.1 The model
sec.p: National censuses typically produce population counts by 5-year age and sex groups, and in the North Carolina example considered here these counts are further broken down by ethnicity. As a result, relative risk is assumed to be constant within 5-year age groups, and baseline rates tend to be treated as known a priori. We use the subscript j to refer to each age–sex–ethnic group (with ethnicity being one of White, African-American, Native-American, Hispanic and Asian) and Sjk to refer to the location of the kth case in the jth group.

The events for each group j are modelled as log Gaussian Cox processes with a common spatial relative risk surface R(s). Given the population Pj(s) and baseline incidence rates Θj for each group, the model is written as (1){Sjk;k=1…Kj}|R(s)~IPP[Mj(s)]amp;Mj(s)=Oj(s)R(s)=ΘjPj(s)R(s) where Oj(s) is the offset surface, can be interpreted as the expected count when R(s) is one. The spatial risk surface R(s) is modelled as an exponentiated Gaussian random field with log[R(s)]=μ+X(s)β+U(s)Cov[U(s),U(s+h)]=σ2Matern(|h|/φ,ν) with φ, ν being the range and roughness parameter respectively of the Matérn spatial correlation function.15 We make the unavoidable assumption that population density is uniform within census regions with Pj(s) = Pjr /||Dr||, where Pjr and ||Dr|| are the area and population count of region Dr. Further, the covariates X(s) are observed at the census tract level, with X(s) = Xr, s ∈ Dr. The problem addressed in the following sections is making inference on the continuous surface U(s) conditional on the observed aggregated counts.

sec.title: 2.2 Inference
sec.p: We use an MCMC algorithm to carry out Bayesian inference, evaluating the posterior distribution of the (vector of) parameters θ = [μ, β, σ, φ] and random effects U(·) = {U(s), s ∈ Ω} conditional on the aggregated counts Y = {Yr, r = 1… R}. MCMC provides an intuitive solution to the problem of area censoring by treating the exact locations Sjk as latent variables. A data augmentation algorithm repeatedly samples from the conditional distribution [S|Y, U(·), θ] and subsequently fit the LGCP model to sample from [θ, U(·)|Y].

sec.title: 2.2.1 Sampling from U(s) and β
sec.p: As with Li et al.,11 we approximate the continuous surface U(s) by a piecewise constant surface evaluated on a lattice of square grid cells. For a lattice of cells Gℓ, ℓ = 1… N covering the study region Ω, define U(s) = Uℓ when s ∈ Gℓ. This approximation serves two purposes. First, it allows the Matérn correlation of the U(s) to be approximated by the GMRF approximation of Lindgren et al.12 where each Uℓ depends only an a small number of nearby cells. This provides an analytical formula for the inverse of the variance matrix of U, which is sparse and therefore tractable even with fine grids with many thousands of cells. Second, having the risk surface constant within cells allows the problem to be reduced to a generalized linear mixed model with Poisson distributed cell counts Yℓ, which are sufficient statistics. As the likelihood of a LGCP depends on the intensity surface evaluated everywhere, rather than only at the locations where cases are observed, piecewise constant approximations for U(s) are implicit in existing algorithms (see e.g. Møller and Waagepetersen16). Combining a grid cell approximation to U(s) with the MRF approximation to the covariance function results in natural and efficient method for sampling from the posterior distribution of LGCPs.

Using a simple extension of the results in Li et al.,11 the counts Yrℓ in the intersections Qrℓ = Gℓ ∩ Dr of cells ℓ and census regions r are sufficient statistics for making inference on the U(s) and β given the Θj. Integrating the intensity surfaces Mj(s) over the Qrℓ and summing over j gives (2) Yrℓ~Poisson(OrℓRrℓ)Orℓ=∑jΘjPjr||Qrℓ||/||Dr||log(Rrℓ)=μ+Xrβ+UℓU1…UL~GMRF(σ,φ,ν)

Here Orℓ is an ‘offset’ term, interpretable as the case count that would be expected were the relative risk equal to one. The BYM model involves an expected count for a census region Er = ∑j Θj Pjr. The expected counts per intersection Qℓr are the Er multiplied by the proportion of region Dr contained within Gℓ. Computing the proportions ||Qrℓ||/||Dr|| is non-trivial but can be calculated with a PostGIS database.

The joint distribution of the Uℓ is a Gaussian Markov Random Field with neighborhood structure, weights, and conditional variance chosen to approximate the Matérn covariance with variance σ2, range φ and roughness ν.12 The sparse precision matrix for U which results from the Markov random field specification makes the evaluation of the likelihoods feasible even for a high dimensional U. A Metropolis–Hastings step proposes new values for U = (U1… UL), φ, σ, μ and β, which are accepted or rejected with probability depending on the ratio of the likelihoods of the new and old values. This is a one block sampling algorithm undertaken because of the strong posterior dependence between U and φ and σ. Details of this step of the algorithm, as well as proposal distributions, are given in Chapter 4 of Rue and Held.17

sec.title: 2.2.2 Data augmentation
sec.p: The data augmentation step overcomes the problem of the case locations Sjk being unknown. It is the count per intersection Yrℓ rather than the complete locations which are required for updating the model parameters in Section 2.2.1, however. The data augmentation step therefore allocates the observed regional count Yr into counts Yrℓ per intersection Qrℓ. The Poisson assumption in (1) results in pr(Sjk∈Gℓ|Sjk∈Dr)=∫QrℓMj(s)ds∑m∫QrmMj(s)ds=exp(Uℓ)||Qrℓ||∑mexp(Um)||Qrm||.

These probabilities are used to simulate case counts for each partition following a multinomial distribution. Note these values do not depend on the group j or covariates Xr, as the terms involving them cancel. The number of updates of θ performed in between data augmentation steps is chosen randomly. This is a form of random scan Gibbs sample,18 though successive iterations of the augmentation step are not performed as the Yrℓ are independent and not retained. Three chains with random starting values were used, each run for 5000 iterations, 10 thinning and 50 burn-ins. The number of updates of θ per iteration is Poisson distributed with mean 15.

sec.title: 3 Simulation study
sec.p: A simulation study replicating the North Carolina syphilis analysis is used to evaluate the proposed methodology and compare it to the BYM model. Simulated risk surfaces are of three types: a rough surface with φ = 10 km; a smooth surface with φ = 60 km; and a surface with a moderate amount of roughness with φ = 30 km. These ranges span the posterior distribution for the range parameter for the real data reported in Section 4 and produced random surfaces were visually very different. For each range, 10 surfaces with variance 0.5 and Matérn correlation with roughness 2 are simulated over North Carolina (300 km × 800 km) on 100 m grids. One categorical urban/rural area indicator covariate and one continuous covariate (log transformed male-to-female ratio) are added, with effect sizes of 0.25 and −1 respectively, which are of the same order of magnitude as that found for the syphilis data in Section 4 and for gonorrhea in Sullivan et al.14

Population data from the US census of 2000 at the census tract level is used along with published national rates for the Θj, as described in Section 4. As the syphilis rates in North Carolina are roughly double the national average, an intercept on the log scale of log(2) is used. Five years of data were generated per simulation, comprising roughly 8500 cases. Three methods are applied and contrasted:
A LGCP model using the exact case locations, as in Li et al.11;
A BYM model based on the aggregated counts per census tract; and
A LGCP fit to the aggregated data, as described in Section 2. Bayesian inference is used for all three models, with INLA used for the first two and the MCMC algorithm in Section 2 for the third. Comparing 3 with 2 assesses the advantage of the proposed method over the standard model, and comparing 3 with 1 quantifies the amount of information which is lost due to data aggregation. Priors from Section 4 for all three analyses, with the BYM model using the same prior for both precision parameters and not making use of the prior on the range parameter.

In disease mapping problems, the question of interest is often to identify regions of abnormally high risk, or ‘hotspots’. We used C to denote the criteria for ‘abnormal’ with, for example, C = 1.5 meaning that an individual's risk is abnormal if it is 50% above ‘normal’. Normal risk levels can be interpreted in two different ways. First, normal risk is the baseline risk for the individual's age–sex group Θj. Second, ‘normal’ is defined as the risk expected given the individual's age–sex group and measured risk factors Xr in their region, or Θj exp(μ + Xrβ). The posterior probability that a location s lies within a hotspot reduces to, for the two definitions above respectively,
pr[R(s) > C|Y] = pr[μ + X(s)β + U(s) > log(C)|Y]
pr[U(s) > log(C)|Y]. The above will be referred to as the exceedance probabilities, with values above 0.8 or 0.95 being regarded as notable.

Figure 2(a) shows a smooth simulated risk surface (range 60 km) with Figure 2(b) to (d) showing exceedance probabilities with C = 1.5 using the second definition above. Figures 2(b) and (c) map exceedance probabilities from an LGCP model using the exact locations and data aggregated to census tracts respectively, while Figure 2(d) is the result from the BYM model. The two LGCP models assign higher posterior probabilities to many of the regions with relative risk above 1.5 in comparison to the BYM model. This is particularly apparent in the far left maps. The exceedance probabilities map for a surface with range 10 km and estimated mean surfaces E(U(s)|Y) for both ranges give similar results and can be found in Figures 8 and 9 in Appendix 1. Figure 2.
Simulated risk surfaces with spatial range parameters φ = 60 km with posterior probabilities of risk being 50% above average pr(exp[U(s)] > 1.5|Y). (a) Range 60 km, true surface, (b) Estimated, LGCP exact data, (c) Estimated, LGCP aggregated data, (d) Estimated BYM model. LGCP: Log-Gaussian Cox process; BYM: Besag, York and Mollié.

To better quantify the differences between the methods, receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves are used to compare the models' ability to identify true high risk areas. Sensitivities and specificities depend both on a risk threshold C and a probability threshold α. Sensitivity, for example, considers only the locations s where U(s) > log(C) and measures the proportion of that area which has posterior probability exceeding α. Low values of α result in most of the locations with exp[U(s)] > C being correctly identified (greater sensitivity), at the expense of many of these regions having been identified high risk incorrectly (low specificity). Varying the probability α between 0.001 and 0.999 for each model and threshold, and comparing the proportions of the regions correctly and incorrectly identified as being above the threshold, produces a range of sensitivity and specificity values which are connected as ROC curves.

A second measure of sensitivity and specificity used calculates the proportion of individuals rather than proportion of surface area in correctly identified. This definition is equivalent to weighting each pixel by its population density when computing area proportions and adds greater emphasis to correct predictions in urban areas. For each of the two exceedance probability definitions, the two types of ROC are calculated. Mean integrated squared error (MISE) is also calculated, both averaged over surface area and averaged over individual. The latter measure multiplies the squared error and the population density surfaces prior to integrating.

sec.title: 3.1 LGCP point versus aggregated data
sec.p:
Shown in Figure 3 are ROCs detecting areas where U(s) > log(2.5). The three subfigures refer to three different range parameters, and the ROCs are all closest to the desirable values in the top left corner when the surface is smoother with range 60 km. The solid and dashed lines refer to inference performed using the aggregated data and exact locations respectively, with black and grey lines corresponding to the piecewise constant approximation to the U(s) being defined on grids of 5 and 15 km cells, respectively. For the smooth surfaces, the choice of grid size does not have a large effect on performance, though the exact data (not surprisingly) gives greater sensitivity and specificity than the aggregated data. For the rough surfaces there is little difference between the inference drawn from exact data and aggregated data when the grid size is small (5 km). One would expect that the Markov random field approximation to the continuous surface would be poor when the grid size is larger than the spatial range, and this is born out by the ROC curves (Figure 3(a)). Performance is consistently better when ROCs are calculated per individual (shown in Figure 11 in Appendix 1) rather than per square kilometer, due to the former giving greater weight to areas with high populations and therefore a larger (and hence more informative) number of cases. Comparison of the MISE for these two models have similar results and are also found in Appendix 1. Figure 3.
ROC curves for detecting exp[U(s)] > 2.5 computed from simulated data using the proposed model with cell sizes (|Gℓ|) 5 km (—), 15 km (—) as well as the model for exact locations with cell sizes 5 km (- - -) and 15 km (- - -) for different ranges, weighted by area. (a) Range 10 km, per square kilometer, (b) Range 30 km, per square kilometer, (c) Range 60 km, per square kilometer.

sec.title: 3.2 LGCP versus BYM
sec.p: This section compares the proposed LGCP model to the widely used BYM model, using aggregated data in both instances. Census tracts in the coastal areas which have no neighbors have been removed, which works to the advantage of BYM.

Figure 4 displays MISE for both the spatial random effect U(s) and risk surface R(s), with x-axis being spatial range parameter in kilometer. The LGCP model consistently shows lower MISE than the BYM model. MISE is higher for the fitted risk surface R(s) than U(s), which is expected as R(s) contains more unknown parameters (β, μ) hence more uncertainty in estimation. ROC's measured per unit area consistently show poorer performance than those measured per person, and this is true for both models. This is to be expected as census tracts are smaller, with the loss of information due to censoring less severe, in areas with high population. The LGCP outperforms the BYM model regardless of the grid size for the approximation of U(s), and the effect of grid size is smaller when the true range is large. Figure 4.
Mean integrated square error (MISE) for the LGCP model with cell size 5 km (—), 15 km (– . –) and BYM model (- - -) for the random effect U(s) (—) and fitted risk R(s) (—) as a function of range parameter in kilometers. (a) MISE per person, (b) MISE per square kilometer. LGCP: log-Gaussian Cox process.

Figure 5 shows the ROC curves for detecting areas with relative risk above C = 2.5 using both measures of risk being ‘excessive’. The LGCP with different grid sizes consistently outperforms the BYM model with the difference being more pronounced with the smoother surface (range 60 km). For a 90% specificity, the proposed model with grid size 5 km can detect 90% of the true high risk areas while BYM detects 70%. ROCs per unit of area are worse than those per person for both models but the difference is smaller for the smoother surface. Again, the effect of grid size on the LGCP model is small when the range is large. Figure 5.
ROC curves computed for the LGCP model with cell size 5 km (—), 15 km (– . –) and BYM model (- - -). Excess risk is defined as U(s) > log(2.5) (—) and μ + X(s)β + U(s) > log(2.5) (—). Data were simulated with spatial range parameters 30 km and 60 km, and results are shown as sensitivity and specificity probabilities per person and per unit of area. (a) Range 30 km, ROC per person, (b) Range 60 km, ROC per person, (c) Range 30 km, square kilometer, (d) Range 60 km, square kilometer.

sec.title: 3.3 Choice of grid size
sec.p: A fine grid will always provide a better approximation to a continuous surface, and the rougher the surface is the greater the advantage of using a fine grid becomes. However, the high dimensionality of the fine grid results in the algorithm being more computationally demanding and memory intensive. Further, proposing samples from the spatial random effect in the MCMC algorithm becomes increasingly difficult as the number of grid cells increases, particularly if the spatial correlation is strong. This results in low acceptance rates and poor mixing of the posterior samples.

When the true risk surface, and therefore the posterior samples, are smooth (with strong spatial correlation), the difference in performance between coarse and fine grids is small. This is evidenced by the small difference between the ROCs for coarse and fine grids in Figure 5(b) and (d). The trade-off between performance and computation would suggest using a grid size smaller than all values of the range parameter judged to be a priori likely, though not so small as to cause low acceptance rates. Based on the results of the simulation study, we use a grid of 15 km for our application, being a quarter of the prior mean of 60 km for the range parameter.

sec.title: 4 Example: Syphilis in North Carolina
sec.p: Here the LGCP model is used to make inference on the spatial variation of syphilis in North Carolina, as described in Section 1. Following Sullivan et al.,14 social risk factors included as covariates are rural urban commuting area (RUCA) and the ratio of males to females. RUCA had four different levels (metropolitan, micropolitan, small town and rural), and was expected to account for daily commuting patterns and hence, the influence of distance on social and sexual networks. As the mountain area of western North Carolina is known to have substantially lower sexually transmitted infection (STI) rates than the rest of the state, an indicator variable was used to divide North Carolina into ‘mountain’ and ‘non-mountain’ regions. Interactions between RUCA and Mountain were also included. The ratio of males to females is truncated to lie between 0.5 and 2 with a change point at 1, and logged.

The dataset consists of cases from 1999 to 2007, and national incidence rates by 5-year age group, for every sex and race combination, are published yearly.19 A slight extension to the model allows for cases from each group j during year t to have intensity ΘjtPj(s)R(s), with baseline rates Θjt fixed a priori at the published rates. As with the model presented in Section 2, fixing the Θjt results in only the case locations being informative and group and year information are discarded. The offset values Orℓ in 2 involve a sum over year t as well as group j, and the rest of the algorithm is unchanged. Note that since there is an intercept in the model, the rates Θjt are only assumed to be correct up to a proportionality constant. Ignoring uncertainty in Θj, and ignoring spatial dependence in estimation, are fairly common in purely spatial models of aggregated data.20 It would, however be possible with individual-level data to integrate the estimation of the Θj into the MCMC algorithm.

The roughness parameter ν and range parameter φ are typically not well identified in spatial models.21 Stein22 showed that the predicted spatial surface depends on the product φσ2 but is insensitive to changes in the individual parameters. As a result, we fix the roughness parameter at 2 and use a Gamma prior for the range with shape 1 and mean 33 km, giving a 95% prior interval between 0.85 km and 123 km. The precision 1/σ2 has a weaker prior of Gamma prior (0.42, 0.00015) giving a 95% interval (0.008, 1.14). The upper 97.5% quantile for σ would give 95% of the Uℓ between −2.3 and 2.3 on the log scale, or relative risks between 0.1 and 10 on the natural scale. Priors used for covariates and intercepts are Gaussian with mean 0 and variance 1000, giving a 95% interval of (−62, 62).

The most significant parameter associated with syphilis rates is the log male to female ratio for regions with more women than men (m:f <1), as shown by the parameter posterior densities in Figure 6(a). Comparing a region with 0.75 men for each woman (the 2.5% quantile of census tracts) to one with equal numbers of men and women (the 25% quantile), with all other factors being equal syphilis risk is 1.8 times higher in the former, with 95% credible interval [1.68, 1.98]. For metropolitan areas, individuals outside of the mountain region have risk 2.17 [1.12, 5.51] times higher than those in the mountains, and individuals in small towns outside mountain regions have risk 1.53 [1.31, 1.81] times higher than similar individuals in metropolitan areas. The remaining parameters are not significantly different from zero, though the intercept parameter has most of the posterior mass above zero indicating that the US national rates by age–sex–race group are lower than the rates in North Carolina. Figure 6.
Prior and posterior density of the hyperparameters and fixed effects. Shown are means (|) , 95% intervals (|) , with shading being proportional to the posterior density (▪▪). (a) Fixed effects (μ, β), (b) Range in kilometers (8νφ), (c) Standard deviation (σ).

Figure 6(b) shows the prior and posterior distribution of φ*=8νφ, which is the smallest distance for which correlation is less than 0.1. Here its posterior mean is roughly 50 km with a credible 95% interval from 30 to 85 km. Figure 6(c) is the prior and posterior distributions of the standard deviation σ, both it and the range parameter exhibit significant deviation from the priors with tighter creditable intervals. The posterior mean of the standard deviation is approximately 0.75 with a 95% interval from 0.5 to 1.25, indicating that the spatial effect U(s) would, for the most part, lie between −1.5 and 1.5 (two standard deviations from zero), or on the natural scale having some locations with over 4 times average risk and others with less than a quarter of the average. Compared to the prior mean of 0.2 giving U(s) remaining in the tighter interval of −0.4 to 0.4, the data are indicating a substantial amount of spatial variation.

Figure 7 maps the posterior means and exceedance probabilities of both the relative risk R(s) and the spatial random effect U(s). Figure 7(a) shows the best estimate of risk relative to the published yearly rates for each age, sex and race group, whereas Figure 7(b) shows the log risk relative to what would be expected given the each region's known risk factors (covariates). The covariates, especially the male–female ratio, explained part of the spatial variation, causing some high risk areas in Figure 7(b) to disappear when comparing with 7(a). The posterior probability plots of Figure 7(c) and (d) which show the probability that risk is more than 5 times the national baseline rates and the rates predicted by each region's social covariates respectively. Many of the regions colored red in Figure 7(c) have a low proportion of male residents, and the high risk is for the most part explained by this imbalance. Accordingly, there are many fewer red regions in Figure 7(d). The areas which remain red in Figure 7(d), in the south east of the state (south of Fayetteville and Wilmington), have high risk for reasons unrelated to a male–female imbalance or to other covariates. Convergence and mixing of the Markov chains is discussed in Appendix 2.

sec.title: 5 Discussion
sec.p: This article presents the spatially continuous LGCP as a feasible and powerful alternative to the conventional BYM model2 for disease mapping. Compared to the spatially discrete BYM model, the proposed LGCP/data augmentation method produced more accurate risk maps as measured by MISE, and better ability to detect ‘hot spots’ as measured by ROC curves.

The LGCP model was used to estimate spatial variation in syphilis risk in North Carolina, as well as to make inference on the effect of spatially varying risk factors. The ratio of males to females proved to be the most important covariate, with increasing the proportion of males resulting in reduced syphilis risk. This is consistent with the hypothesis that when females have a greater choice in sexual partners they are better able to avoid higher risk sexual activity.14,23 The change point at equal numbers of males and females, beyond which increasing the proportion of males has no effect on risk, would suggest that the number of high risk men is small and a balanced sex ratio is sufficient for females to avoid them.

The spatial range parameter has a posterior mean of roughly 50 km, which is an intuitive result as it represents roughly 40 min to 1-h driving time. The interpretability of the range parameter is a further advantage of the LGCP over the BYM model, as the usual measure of dependence for the BYM model σ2/σ2 + τ2 is closely tied to the census geographies and can be difficult to explain to applied scientists.

The key assumption made with this LGCP model, and a significant difference between this model and BYM, is spatial stationarity with the correlation between risk at two locations depending only on distance between them and not on the locations themselves. It is possible that correlation decays more strongly in urban areas than rural areas as individuals would not travel as far to find sexual partners. It is equally possible that spatial dependence is stronger in and around cities as residents in the surrounding areas might be likely to travel large distances to a city for employment or leisure purposes. A solution to this problem is to apply this model with a different metric system, for example, distance measured by driving time or some population-based measures, such methods ‘stretch’ the urban area so that urban and rural area are on the same scale therefore transforming a non-stationary process to be stationary, often referred as spatial deformation in the literature.24,25 Simulating from various non-stationary models and comparing BYM and the LGCP would likely be illuminating. In some circumstances the BYM may prove an excellent approximation to a continuous process, though BYM seems ill-suited to the very irregular census regions used in this application.

A number of further assumptions made in the model could rightly be questioned and relaxing them would result in extensions of the model. The Matérn roughness parameter is fixed at 2 and would ideally be allowed to vary. The Poisson distribution results from the assumption that individuals are independent conditional on a shared risk surface, which is evidently not the case with an infectious disease such as syphilis. Some combination of a spatial random effects model to account for unobserved covariates and individual-level infectious disease models26 would be ideal, though inference of standard individual-level models is already very computationally intensive for large datasets. Finally, the spatial risk surface should be allowed to vary over time, with a U(s, t) surface having a spatial and a temporal correlation. As the current model is already pushing the boundaries of the MCMC methodology used a more sophisticated algorithm would be needed to deal with the added complexity involved in addressing the above.

The computational efficiency and stability of the algorithm could be improved though a combination of more sophisticated MCMC samplers and better finite-dimensional approximations of the continuous risk surface. The lattice could be irregular, and finer in urban areas where censoring is less severe, or even chosen adaptively as described in the discussion of Lindgren et al.12 However, moving from piecewise constant basis functions to the linear basis functions in Lindgren et al.12 would result in cell counts no longer being sufficient statistics. A solution to low acceptance rates for fine grids with strong correlation could be the Langevin and Hamiltonian MCMC algorithms of Girolami and Calderhead,27 where impressive chain convergence was demonstrated for a LGCP (albeit on a small 64 × 64 grid).

sec.title: Markov chain diagnostics
sec.p:
Figure 12 shows the trace plot of the range φ* and standard deviation σ. These two parameters mixed the least well of all the parameters and random effects in the model, with the range parameter is mixing less well than the standard deviation. The other model parameters have trace plots which are much closer to independent (Figure 18). The authors have often seen trace plots similar to those in Figure 12 for the intercept and standard deviations in the BYM model. Figure 12.
Trace plot of posterior samples with chain 1 (—), chain 2 (—) and chain 3 (– . –). (a) Range (φ*) in kilometer, (b) standard deviation (σ).

To explore the behavior of the data augmentation step, trace plots of posterior risk and case allocation on selected cells and census regions are produced. Figure 13 shows the trace plots of posterior samples of Uℓ as well as the number of cases allocated to Gℓ from three different chains for two selected cells. Cell 367 is in a sparsely populated rural area where there are very few cases and the cell intersects 5 census tracts. Only 14 of the 1500 posterior samples allocate a case to cell 367, and the random effect is for the most part negative. In contrast, cell 411 is in a populated area, intersects 8 census tracts, each of which containing a large number of cases. On average, 100 cases are allocated to the cell though the number varies between 80 and 120. This number of cases is higher than the population in the cell would predict, and the log relative risk U411 is well above zero. Figure 14 plots the posterior means for case counts and relative risk for Census Tracts (a, b), Census Tract and grid cell intersections (c, d), and grid cells (e, f). Note there is a tendency for cases to be allocated to cells and partitions with high relative risk, a phenomenon most apparent in the large Census Tract at the southern tip of the state. Figure 13.
Trace plot of posterior samples of two selected grid cells and the case allocations, with chain 1 (—), chain 2 (—) and chain 3 (– . –). (a) Risk for cell 367 (Uℓ), (b) Cases allocated to cell 367 (Yℓ), (c) Risk for cell 411 (Uℓ), (d) Cases allocated to cell 411 (Yℓ).

Figure 15 shows the cases trace plots for two selected Census Tracts, with ID 37155961900 and 37163970500 from three different chains. These two Census Tracts were selected in a way that the intersecting partitions within them are about the similar size or the ‘bigger’ partitions within the Census Tracts are of the similar sizes, so that we can see how cases in the census tract were allocated to each partitions. Figure 15(a) gives the case trace plot for region 37155961900 (shown ▪ in Figure 17), this Census Tracts has 16 cases and 6 partitions and cases in the three largest partition were plotted in different colors as they made up more than 80% of the region. Two of the partitions are about same size (25%) and the third one takes about 35%. From the plot it is obvious that cases are pretty evenly allocated into these two smaller partitions (— and —), and a fewer more cases in the larger partition (—). Census Tracts 37163970500 (shown ▪ in Figure 17) has 2 cases and 5 partitions, while 2 partitions of size 40% and 53% made up most of the region. Figure 15(b) illustrates that the distribution of the 2 cases over time, with the large partition (—) has 2 cases more often than the smaller one (—). Figure 14.

Figure 16 shows sampled case counts for all the partitions in two randomly selected census tracts. Figure 16(a) refers to a census tract with 32 cases in 6 partitions, with Figure 16(b) having 13 cases and 2 unequally sized partitions. Chains on both plots show good mixing, with majority of the cases assigned the bigger partitions. Figure 17 shows the locations of the census tracts.
